texts.en: Elisabeth O. is 45 years old and married with seven children. She lives in Itegbe, Lagos state, Nigeria. Elisabeth has been selling kerosene since 2003. Kerosene is an essential commodity in Nigeria and is in high demand. Elisabeth needs the loan amount of $425 to buy more kerosene to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Essenam

texts.fr: Essenam Y. est âgée de 49 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle habite à Danyi, un village situé à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle tient depuis plus de 2 ans une boutique d’alimentation  générale qui est sa principale source de revenu. Elle souhaite par ce crédit alimenter sa boutique pour mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. Les revenus de son activité l’aideront à mieux subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Essenam Y. is 49 years old, married, and the mother of five. She lives in Danyi, a village located about 170 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. She has had for two years a shop for grocery items that is her main source of income. She would like to use this loan to keep the shop going in order to meet the demands of her customers better. The income from her business will improve her ability to provide for her children's needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of soap and milk and sacks of rice for resale

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna E. sells cooked foods like rice, beans, yams, and plantains, as well as drinks. She learned the skill of selling from her auntie. Anna is 38 years old and married with nine children. She is a LAPO client. Anna lives in Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of $425 to buy one deep freezer to cool her drinks. This, she says, will increase her sales. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy a deep freezer

loans.name: Glory

texts.en: Glory E. is 42 years old and married with five children. Glory is a LAPO client. Glory sells foodstuffs and provisions, such as butter, milk, sugar, and detergent. Glory lives in Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of $1200 to buy more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en:
Fumilayo S. lives in Sabo Ajamgbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells provisions and drinks. She started this business in 2002. Fumilayo is 36 years old and married with 5 children.

She is a LAPO client. Fumilayo asks for a loan amount of $425 to buy more foods and provisions for sale. She says thank you to kiva lenders

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Nihifadhi

texts.en:
Nihifadhi is 42 years old. She is divorced with 3 children aged 19, 7 and 6 years old. She has run her own phone accessories shop since 2006. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Nihifadhi now hopes for a loan to buy phone accessories to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more phone accessories to expand her business.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana M. is hoping to take out her first loan, a small one, with NGO GHAPE in the town of Bamenda. She lives in Cameroon's North West province and has five children, four of whom are still at home. Susana would like to use the money to expand the output of her farm. Specifically, she plans to till the land and buy seedlings to plant; she also intends to buy five chicks to raise for meat. She says that with the increased income this will generate, she would like to help her children to start out in work. Eventually, she would also like to build a house and save some money to fall back on should she ever get sick.

loans.use: Purchase of seedlings and chicks.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mwatum's Mkorofi Si Mwenzetu Group

texts.en:
Mwatum is 32 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 14, 9 and 1. She has been a clothes seller since 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

Mwatum is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Salhina.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace T. N. is married and the mother of nine children. Her mother passed away recently, after Grace had taken care of her for many years. Her son also died a mysterious death in a nearby river. This was an especially great tragedy because Grace was very close to him, and because he helped care for his younger brothers and sisters. Recently cows did a lot of damage to her crops. Because of these unfortunate events, Grace became a member of GHAPE in 2002.

Grace has successfully repaid four loans, with a total value of $420. She invested these loans in farming coco yams, beans and maize, and in raising piglets, pigs and pig feed. The profits from these loans helped her pay school fees for children, buy medicines and meet other basic needs like food.

Grace is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more pigs, which she will fatten and sell. She is convinced that her business is going to succeed because she has a lot of experience in pig farming, and because there is a steady market for pigs and pig feed in her community. She plans to use the profit from this loan to expand her business, pay off her loan, provide medicine for her family, pay school fees and meet other needs.

She plans to repay this loan in 24 months, with the first payment due four months after disbursement.

loans.use: Pig farming

loans.name: Kazija's Tusisahau Kwetu. Group

texts.en:
Kazija is 42 years old. She is married with 6 children between the ages of 36 and 3 years old. She has been a charcoal and firewood seller since 2000. Every day, she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Kazija now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Moza, Maryam and Mwajuma.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther was born in 1940 and is married and the mother of four children, two of whom are under 15 years old. Her only daughter, who was married, died after a protracted illness, leaving behind three children who Esther now cares for.

Esther is not educated and because of poverty, hardships and the death of her husband struggles to educate er children, clothe them, pay hospital bills and provide them three square meals a day. Esther joined GHAPE three years ago and has successfully repaid two loans, both of which she invested in buying and selling pigs and fowl, and farming of cassava. The profit from these loans has helped enormously in paying school fees and hospital bills and increasing the size of her farm.

With her latest loan, Esther intends to increase the size of her farm by buying more pigs and fowl and by farming more cassava. Her business is going to succeed because there is a ready market for her products. Due to her longevity in this business, she is well known in her community for raising healthy animals and has a lot of customers who come from far and near.

Esther plans to repay this loan in 18 months with the first installment repayment due four months after disbursement.

loans.use: Buying of farm seeds and rearing of fowls.

loans.name: Asma

texts.en:
Asma is 30 years old. She is married with one child, aged 12 years old. She has been a clothes seller since 1998. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Asma now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes (bedsheets) for her business.

loans.name: Mashavu

texts.en:
Mashavu is 49 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 20, 11 and 7 years old. She is a charcoal and firewood seller. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Mashavu now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood to increase her stock.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en:
Bridget is married and has eight children, four of whom are under 15 years of age. The recent death of her father has made life very difficult and sad for her. But Bridget saw GHAPE as a source of hope, and quickly enrolled to become a member. Since that time she has received and repaid five loans, and has been able to feed her family, pay her children's school fees and clothe them. 

If Brigit receives a new loan, she will use it to rent a palm tree plantation and produce palm oil as well as buy and raise fowl for sale. She has promised to start repayment on the fourth month after disbursement, and will to use the profit generated by the loan to pay school fees and expand her business. 

Brigit is a big fan of loans from GHAPE because of the training it offers and its good repayment terms.

loans.use: To rent a palm tree plantation for oil production and to buy chickens to raise and sell.

loans.name: Kiboga

texts.en:
Kiboga is 22 years old.  She is divorced with 2 children aged 6 and 3 years old.  She has been a cigarette and pure water seller since 2006.  Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Kiboga is now looking for a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Chinelo

texts.en:
Chinelo O. lives in Alaba, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells clothes and she is also a fashion designer. She learned how to sew 3 years ago. She is a LAPO client.

Chinelo started this business in 2005. She is 25 years old and married without a child. She is requesting a loan amount of $850 to buy more clothes to sell, so that she can expand her business and increase her profit margin. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Zoumana

texts.fr:
Monsieur Kanté Zoumana âgé de 48 ans, marié et  père de 7 enfants. Il vit dans une famille polygame avec ses deux épouses, ses enfants et ses parents dans le quartier Bamannankin de Ouelessebougou (une des sous préfectures de la région de Koulikoro). Il exerce la boucherie depuis 12 ans. Cette activité est une activité familiale et était exercé par son père auprès duquel il la apprit. Il exerce cette activité au marché de Ouelessebougou situé au bord de la route reliant le Mali à La république de Cote d’ivoire.
Dans son souci d’élargir son activité et de faire face à une demande de plus en plus croissante, monsieur Kanté décida de s’adresser à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel. Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter deux bœufs en raison de 125.000 FCFA  l’unité. Les bœufs sont abattus et vendu au détail à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes et de restaurateurs. L’abattage est effectué chaque deux jours. Monsieur Zoumana Kanté mène une activité très rentable et compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 135.000 FCFA. Une grande partie de ce bénéfice est utilisée pour faire face aux dépenses de la famille élargie (père, mère, sœurs, frères, femmes et enfants).
A la longue il compte construire une boucherie moderne lui permettant de respecter les normes sanitaires.
texts.en:
Mr. Zoumana Kanté is 48 years old, married and the father of 7 children. He lives in a polygamous family with two spouses, his children and his relatives in the Bamannankin district of Ouelessebougou (one of the subprefectures of the Koulikoro region). He has worked as a butcher for 12 years. This is a family profession and he learned it from his father who was also a butcher. He runs this business at the Ouelessebougou market located along the road connecting Mali and the Republic of the Ivory Coast. Concerned about expanding his business and faced with an ever-growing demand, Mr. Kanté decided to go to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is his first individual loan. It will be used to buy two steers at a cost of 125,000F CFA each. The steers are slaughtered and sold as retail to a clientele made up primarily of women and restaurant owners. The slaughtering takes place every two days. Mr. Zoumana Kanté runs a very profitable business and hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 135,000F CFA. A large part of this revenue is used to deal with the expenses of his large family (father, mother, sisters, brothers, wives and children). Eventually he plans to build a modern butchery allowing him to respect health standards.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of steers for butchering

loans.name: Olubisi

texts.en:
Olubisi S. sells provisions and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. Olubisi needs a deep freezer to cool her drinks for her customers.

Olubisi is 37 years old and married with 3 children. She is a LAPO client and lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria. She needs a loan amount of $425 to buy one deep freezer so that she can cool her drinks for her customers. Olubisi says that this will increase her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and one deep freezer

loans.name: Mtumwa's Sitaki Shari Group

texts.en:
Mtumwa is 34 years old. She is divorced. She has been a clothes seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 8:30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $145 from her sales.

Mtumwa is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Khadia and Jaalia.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence T. lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria. She grinds pepper, tomatoes, and corn. She started this business in 2001. She has a grinding machine at the front of her house. This enables her to start grinding pepper, tomatoes, and corn for her customers by 7:00 am. She stops grinding at 8:00 pm daily.

Florence is 50 years old. She is married with 4 children. She is a LAPO client. Florence needs the loan amount of $850 to buy one grinding machine so that she can meet the demands of her numerous customers. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy one grinding machine

loans.name: Futari's Tuaminiane Group

texts.en:
Futari is 32 years old. She is widow with 2 children aged 6 and 3 years old. She runs her own phone accessories shop and she has been a charcoal seller since 2003. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Futari now hopes for a loan to buy more phone accessories and charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Naeshe.

loans.use: To buy more phone accessories and charcoal to expand her business.

loans.name: Benkadi(L'entente Est Bonne Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe benkadi résident au village de Djodjandjè de la sous préfecture de Ouelessebougou. Elles sont mariées et vivent dans des foyers polygames avec en moyenne 27 ans et 2 enfants. Elles se sont connues par des liens de famille, de voisinage. 

Elles exercent toutes le petit commerce d’articles divers (tubercules, charbon de bois, friandises . . .). Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter des sacs de tubercules, des sacs de charbon et des matières premières. Elles s’approvisionnent mensuellement sur place et dans les villages environnants.
 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt et compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 18.500 FCFA.
texts.en:
The women in the Benkadi group live in the village of Djodjandjè in the subprefecture of Ouelessebougou. They are married and live in polygamous households with an average age of 27 years old and have an average of 2 children each. They met through neighborhood and family ties. They all work in the small-scale business of selling various items (tubers, charcoal, candy, etc.). With this loan, they plan to buy bags of tubers, charcoal and raw materials. They get their supplies every month in surrounding villages. This is their second loan and they plan to earn an average monthly profit of 18,500F CFA.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items for their small business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose V. is 45 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria. Rose sells foods like tubers of yam, Garri, palm oil, and corn. She has been in this business since 2000. Rose is a LAPO client.

She needs the loan amount of $850 to buy more food for sale. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
Kemi G. lives in Ojo-Alaba, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells drinks, wine, and juice from the front of her house. She has been in this business since the year 2003. Kemi is 32 years old and married with 2 children. She begins her sales each day by 6:30 am and ends sale each day by 8:00 pm. Her customers are mostly her neighbours.

She has been a LAPO client for more than a year. Kemi needs the loan amount of $850 to buy more drinks, wine, and juice for sale. She says that this will increase the growth of her business and also her profits. She says thank you to kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, wine, and juice for sale

loans.name: Djékafo(Soyons Ensemble) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djékafo sont des femmes mariées vivant en général dans des foyers polygames avec en moyenne 1 enfant et résident dans le village de djodjandjè de la sous préfecture de Ouelessebougou. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et d’amitié et exercent l’activité de restauration et le petit commerce d’articles divers (produits laitiers et friandises. ..).
Elles s’approvisionnent hebdomadairement sur place et vendent au marché du village et les marchés des villages environnants..

Les femmes du groupe Djékafo sont à leur deuxième prêt. elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 22.000 FCFA par femme. elles comptent améliorer leur condition de vie avec le système de prêt de groupe solidaire de l’institution de micro finance SORO YIRIWASO.
texts.en:
The members of the Djékafo group are married women generally living in polygamous households with an average of one child each and residing in the village of Djodjandjè in the subprefecture of Ouelessebougou. They met through friends, family and neighbors and work in the restaurant business as well as the sale of various items (dairy products and candy...). They get their supplies locally on a daily basis and sell them at the village market and the markets in surrounding villages. The women of the Djékafo group are requesting their second loan. They plan on earning an average monthly profit of 22,000F CFA each. They plan on improving their living conditions with the group loan program through the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items for small business

loans.name: Tinuke

texts.en:
Tinuke A. sells prayer items like candles, olive oil, and prayer books in her shop. She has been in this business for the past 15 years. She is married, has 4 children, and she is 49 years old.

She has been a leader in a lending group for the past 3 years and she lives in Ajamgbadi Lagos state, Nigeria. Tinuke need a loan of $425 to buy more prayer materials for her business expansion and for profit growth. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more prayer items like olive oil, candles, and prayer books for sale

loans.name: Saada's Tusonge Mbele Group

texts.en:
Saada is 30 years old. She is married with 4 children aged 13, 12, 8 and 6 years old. She has been a firewood seller since 2004. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Saada is now requesting a loan to buy more firewood for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Mtumwa, Asha, Christina and Kesi.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her businesss.

loans.name: Kolagnini (Searching) Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kolagnini résident dans le village de djodjandjè de la sous préfecture de Ouelessebougou. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames traditionnelles élargies et ont en moyenne 22 ans et trois (3) enfants.
Elles se sont connues au village à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié, famille. Elles exercent le commerce de produits alimentaires et d’articles pour femmes. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire) avec Soro Yiriwaso après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des fruits et légumes, des parures pour femmes (parfums, boucles d’oreille, bracelet ) auprès de grossistes à Bamako (capitale du Mali).. Les articles sont revendus sur place au village et dans les foires des villages environnants. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.500 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The women of the group Kolagnini live in the city Djodjandjè within the Ouelessebougou prefecture. They live with traditional polygamous extended families. On average they are 22 years old and have three children. They met in their village through neighbors, friends, and family. For their businesses, they sell food products and women’s products. This is their second group loan with Soro Yiriwaso; they successfully paid back their first loan. They are planning to use the loan to purchase fruits and vegetables and finery for women (perfumes, earrings, and bracelets) from wholesalers at Bamako, the capital of Mali. The products will be resold in the village and in the fairs of surrounding villages. They hope to make a monthly profit of 25,500 FCFA, which will allow them to help with the need of the family.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase different items for the small business

loans.name: Chidi Ogo

texts.en:
Chidi ogo I. sells cooked foods like rice, beans, plantain, yam, drinks, and juice. She has been in this business for a long time. Chidi wakes up as early as 4:00 am to start the cooking tasks for each day. She loves her business; her customers pay in cash when they come to buy cooked foods, drinks, and juice.

Chidi ogo is 34 years old and is married with 4 children. She is a LAPO client. Chidi ogo lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She needs a loan amount of $425 to buy more drinks and juice for sale. She says this will go a long way to help her in meeting the demands of her customers. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible

loans.use: To buy more drinks and juice to sell.

loans.name: Mwajuma's Tujiamini Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 26 years old. She is married with 4 children aged 9, 6, 4 and 1. She has been a phone voucher, beans and charcoal seller since 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Mwajuma is now looking for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwanausi.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Chinoye

texts.en:
Chinoye O. sells second-hand shoes and bags. She has been in her business for the past three years. She is 32 years old and single. She lives at Ajamgbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. Chiniye is a hard-working woman. She begins her sales daily by 8:00 am and ends her day at 7:00 pm. She is a LAPO client.

The demand for her second-hand shoes and bags are high because her customers find her prices affordable. She needs the loan amount of $425 to buy more second-hand bags and shoes for sale. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more second hand shoes and bags for sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort O. is 50 years old and married with 4 children. She is a LAPO client. Comfort sells fruit like bananas, apples, and mangoes. She started selling fruit in 2008.

Comfort lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She needs a loan of $425 to buy more fruit for sale. She says this will enable her to meet the demands of her customers. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more fruit like bananas, apples, and mangoes to sell.

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr: Maïmouna S. est âgée de 23 ans et mariée. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son petit commerce qui consiste à acheter de la graine d'arachide, à la transformer en pate pour la revendre. cette activité lui permettra de subvenir à ses besoins et de contribuer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille. <b>Elle va rembourser ce prêt en une seule échéance au bout de six mois<b/>.
texts.en:
Maïmouna S., 23, is married. She is requesting this loan to bolster her little business buying peanuts and transforming them into peanut butter. This activity will permit her to support herself and contribute to the daily expenses of the family. She is going to reimburse this loan in one single repayment at the end of 6 months.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of peanut butter

loans.name: Jasmina

texts.en:
Jasmina is 31 years old and has two children, aged 13 and 15.  Her husband has a full time job and Jasmina works as a bakery assistant.  She earns about 150 KM monthly, which is not enough for the needs of her household.

Jasmina now has one cow and a calf.  She intends to use the loan of 600 KM, along with some money she has saved, to buy another cow. She can earn more money by selling milk and milk products, and a calf for Ramadan (Muslim holiday) than she can by working at her current job.

loans.use: To buy another cow.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Gorette

texts.en:
Greetings from Gorette in her beauty salon business in Kigali, Rwanda. Gorette is 39 years old and a single mother of two children and four adopted orphans of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.

Gorette, who has been in the credit association since 2004, also works in the African Library. In addition to that, her salon business in Kigali attracts many working-class clients. She employs two people in her salon. She earns about $150 per month from her business. One of the challenges in her business is not having enough equipment in the hair salon, especially for women clients. 

She is looking for a loan worth 500,000 Frws to buy two hair-drying helmets for her salon.

loans.use: To buy two hair-drying helmets for her salon

loans.name: Bisi

texts.en: Bisi O. lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 41 years old and married with six children. Bisi runs a business selling firewood and charcoal, mostly to her neighbors.  Bisi is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 USD to buy more firewood and charcoal to sell. She extends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouma(Lucky) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma résident dans le village de djodjandjè et sont des femmes mariées vivant en général dans des foyers polygames avec en moyenne 30 ans et cinq (5) enfants. Elles se sont connues au village par des liens d’amitié, d’affaire ou de voisinage.
Elles exercent le petit commerce de condiments alimentaires, de charbon de bois et de pagnes. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt et comptent l’utiliser pour constituer un stock des articles ci-dessus cités. Elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès de grossistes attitrés. Les ventes sont réalisées sur place au village et dans les marchés des villages environnants (sur étale ou en ambulant).
Les femmes envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 19.000 FCFA. qui sera utilisé pour agrandir la taille de leurs activités et faire face aux charges familiales.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sabougnouma live in the village Djodjandjè. They are married women that generally live in polygamous households. On average, they are 30 years old and have five children. They met in their village through business friends and neighborhood friends. Their small businesses are of condiments, wood coal, and African fabrics. This is their second loan and they hope to use it to increase their current inventory. They will purchase the goods in Bamako, the capital of Mali, from their regular wholesalers. Their goods are sold in their village and also the markets of the surrounding villages. The goods are put on display or sold in the street. The women hope to make a monthly profit of 19,000 FCFA, which will be used to expand the size of their businesses and meet family expenses.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various items for small businesses

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence O. lives in Ilaje, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells local gin, popularly known in Nigeria as "ogogoro". Local gin comes from palm trees. When sap has been tapped from the palm tree, it is now boiled for few hours, after which it is mixed with local herbs and put into bottles. This is served as local gin.

Most of Florence's customers are men. Florence is a LAPO client. She is 33 years old and married with 6 children. She has been selling local gin for the past 2 years. She needs the loan amount of US$ 275 to buy more local gin (ogogoro) for sale.

loans.use: To buy more hot drinks (ogogoro)

loans.name: Maï

texts.fr: Maï C. est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle veut avec ce prêt pouvoir améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de ses enfants. Elle souhaite renforcer le capital de son activité qui consiste à acheter de la graine d’arachide, à la transformer en pate afin de la revendre.  Elle veut aussi en même temps acheter et revendre du nététou (graine d’un arbre transformée en produit alimentaire local), commerce très rentable. <b>Elle remboursera ce prêt au bout de six mois en une seule échéance <b/>.
texts.en:
Maï C. is married and the mother of three children. She wants to be able to improve, through this loan, the living conditions, health and education of her children. She wishes to strengthen the capital of her business, which consists of buying peanut seeds to turn into peanut butter, which she then sells. At the same time she wants to buy and sell netetou (seeds from the Nere tree that are turned into a local food), a very profitable business. She will repay this loan after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds to turn into peanut butter for onward sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy palm oil, piglets and seeds.

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr:
Madame Bintou Traoré est âgée de 27 ans et vit avec ses 2 enfants et son mari dans une famille monogame au quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région économique de la république du Mali).
N’ayant jamais été à l’école, Madame Bintou Traoré fut initié aux activités commerciales depuis sa tendre enfance par sa grande mère. Elle a un grand sens des affaires grâce à une dizaine d’année expérience accumulée dans l’exercice de cette activité. 
Après 5 prêts (en solidaire de groupe) avec Soro Yiriwaso tous correctement remboursés ; elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour l’achat de matières premières : 5 cartons de jus en poudre, 150 kg de sucre, 1 paquet de sachet plastique, 2 sacs de dah, 3 paquets de vanille, 20kg de zinzimbre. Elle s’approvisionne sur place au grand marché de Ségou.
Jouissant d’une grande réputation dans cette activité de transformation de fruits en boissons non alcoolisées, elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout lors des cérémonies (Mariages, baptême etc.…).En plus des commandes, elle vend quotidiennement chez elle à domicile, au marché du quartier Médine (au comptant) et de façon ambulante à une clientèle très variée. La rentabilité de son activité est visible et avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000 FCFA qu’elle compte utiliser pour intensifier son activité en achetant un deuxième réfrigérateur.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bintou Traoré is 27 years old and lives with her two children and her husband in a monogamous household. She lives in the Médine district in Ségou, the fourth largest economic region in the Republic of Mali. Having never gone to school, Mrs. Bintou Traoré started her businesses after her early childhood spent with her grandmother. She is very business savvy thanks to the ten or so years of experience in this business. After five group loans with Soro Yiriwaso that were all successfully paid back, she is asking for a second individual loan. She plans to use this loan to buy the necessary materials: five cartons of powdered juice, 150 kilograms of sugar, one package of plastic bags, two sacks of roselle, three packets of vanilla, and 20 kilograms of ginger. She will purchase the goods at the market in Ségou. As she enjoys a good reputation in the business of transforming fruits into non-alcoholic drinks, she receives many orders, particularly during ceremonies (marriages, baptisms, etc.). On top of orders, she sells her product daily for cash at her house, at the market in her district Médine, and in the street. Her clientele is extremely varied. The profitability of her business is visible and with her loan she hopes to make a monthly profit of 60,000 FCFA, which she will use to strengthen her business by purchasing a second refrigerator.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials for the transformation of fruits to juices

loans.name: Kadidia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadidia Touré est une veuve âgée de 64 ans qui vit avec ses 11 enfants au domicile de son feu époux au 3ème quartier de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Comme beaucoup de femmes du continent Africain d’une manière générale et en république du Mali en particulier, elle n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école. Elle fut obligée dès son jeune âge de s’essayer à plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus. Après beaucoup d’échecs, elle décida de se spécialiser dans la vente des boissons gazeuses de fabrication moderne et de la glace depuis maintenant 20 ans. 
En relation avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans, elle a bénéficié de trois prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) avec une association de son quartier et deux prêts individuels tous remboursés correctement.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, 12 casiers de boissons gazeuses, un moteur pour son réfrigérateur avec lequel elle a commencé l’activité et une charrette (pousse-pousse) pour le transport de la glace et des casiers de boissons fraîches. Cette activité est menée chaque jour et la vente se fait à domicile au marché et en ambulant à une clientèle variée.
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 42 000 FCFA qui sera essentiellement utilisé pour renforcer le fonds de commerce. Dans l’avenir elle compte ouvrir un dépôt de boissons.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadidia Toure is a 64 year old widow who lives with her 11 children in the house of her late husband which is located in the third district of Segou (the fourth administration region of the Republic of Mali).

Like many women of the African continent in general and those of the Republic of Mali in particular, she did not have the opportunity to attend school. She was obliged at an early age to try many different business activities to earn an income. Twenty years ago, after a number of set-backs, she decided to specialize in the sale of the latest soft drinks and ice.

She has had an association with the Soro Yiriwaso microbank for three (3) years and has made three (3) group loans as part of a neighborhood association and two (2) personal loans. All of these have been successfully repaid. With this new loan, she plans to buy 12 crates of soft drinks, a motor for her refrigerator (the one she started the business with), and a push cart to transport the ice and soft drink crates. Her business is increasing each day, with sales being made from her home, at the market, and door-to-door to a wide variety of clients.

With this loan Mrs.Toure expects to earn a monthly profit of 42,000 francs CFA which will be used mainly to increase her operating fund. In the future she would like to open a soft drink warehouse.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of soft drinks.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary O. sells foodstuffs like tubers of yam, plantain, garri, and cocoa yam. She also makes and sells beads. She learned how to make beads from her mother. Mary is 30 years old and married with a child. She is a client of LAPO. She needs the loan amount of $850 to buy more foodstuffs for sale and bead materials for her to make more beads. This, she says, will enable her satisfy her numerous customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and bead making  materials

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia M. is 26 and married with a three year-old daughter. She owns a shop in Buguruni where she sells used electronics. She has owned this shop for five years and works daily from 8 am to 5 pm. She's done well with this business and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $868.

Rukia has taken two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used them to collect stock from Zanzibar and has repaid both successfully. With this loan, she intends to move her shop. The place she currently has increased the monthly rent so she hopes to move her business to an area called Kinondoni.

loans.use: To move her shop to Kinondoni.

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Madame Rokia T. âgée de 56 ans, est une veuve et mère de 8 enfants qui vit à Bougouni un village environnant de la ville de Ségou (préfecture de Ségou quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Initiée aux activités génératrices de revenus par sa mère, elle exerce le commerce de pagnes wax et de fancy (tissus très prisés en Afrique de l’Ouest ) il y’a de cela 8 ans. 
Etant en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans, elle a bénéficié de 6 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et est à son deuxième individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 50 pièces de pagnes Wax et 10 pièces de pagnes Fancy auprès des commerçants grossistes de la capitale malienne Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant et souvent à crédit de façon fixe au marché journalier du village et en ambulant (les pagnes mis dans une tasse) dans les quartiers de Bougouni les petits soirs à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes et de quelques d’hommes. 
Seule à mener l’activité d’achat et de vente de pagnes dans le village de Bougouni, donc sans concurrent elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qu’elle compte utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et renforcer le fonds de commerce. Son ambition est de construire une maison pour ses orphelins.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rokia T. is a 56 years old widow and mother of eight (8) children. She lives in Bougouni, a village on the outskirts of the city of Segou (the prefecture of Sagou is the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

She was taught by her mother in the ways of earning income through different business activities. Over the past eight (8) years she has been active in the business of selling "pagne" (decorative cloth). She has been associated with the Soro Yiriwaso microbank for five (5) years and has made six (6) group loans and is now on her second personal loan. All the loans have been repaid.

Mrs. T. plans to use this loan to buy 50 pieces of Wax brand pagne and 10 pieces of Fancy brand pagne from wholesalers in the Malian capital city of Bamako. She will resell these items for cash or credit at the daily village market and also through door-to-door selling (carrying her pagne, folded neatly in a head basket) during the evenings, in the Bougouni neighborhoods, to a clientele made up mostly of women and some men.

She is the leader in the buying and selling of pagne in the village of Bougouni. Without any competition she expects to earn a profit of 90,000 francs CFA which she will spend to meet the loan payments, provide for family expenses and support her business activities. Her ambition is to build a home for orphan children.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pagne (decorative cloth): Wax brand and Fancy brand

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sadio

texts.fr: Sadio D. est mariée, 43 ans et mère de 08 enfants. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer le capital de son activité qui consiste à acheter de la graine d’arachide, à la transformer en pate afin de la revendre. Elle souhaite ainsi pouvoir améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé de sa famille et assurer une bonne scolarité à ses enfants. <b>Elle compte rembourser en une seule échéance au bout de six mois<b/>.
texts.en:
Sadio D. is 43 years old, married and the mother of eight children. She is requesting this loan to boost the capital of her business, which consists of buying peanut seeds to turn into peanut butter to sell. In this way she wants to be able to improve the living conditions and health of her family and ensure that her children have a good education. She aims to repay the loan in a single installment after six months.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds and turn them into peanut butter for sale

loans.name: Aoua

texts.fr:
Madame Aoua Traoré  est une femme de 40 ans, mère de 2 enfants (1 fille et 1 garçon) qui vit dans une famille polygame avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants à Koboïla II, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la République du Mali).
Secrétaire Dactylo de formation, elle est issue d’une famille de teinturière de Quinzanbougou un des quartiers de Bamako( capitale de la république du Mali). Elle mène cette activité (qu’elle avait mise en veilleuse pour des raisons d’études) depuis bientôt 10 ans. Très connue et appréciée et sa clientèle ne cesse d’augmenter de jour en jour.
Afin de satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle rejoint le programme crédit de l’institution Soro Yiriwaso il y’a 2 ans . Elle est à son premier prêt (prêt individuel) et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 18 pièces de bazin blanc (tissus très prisé en afrique de l’ouest), 250kg de soude caustique et 19 kg de teinture de couleurs différentes.
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako en matières premières (bazins blancs, soude caustique et teintures) Elle teint les tissus dans son atelier en face de son domicile. Ensuite elle les revend au comptant ou à crédit; généralement à des revendeuses des bazins teintés, à des couturiers de la place  et à certaines femmes de son quartier.
 MadameAoua Traoré envisage réaliser un bénéfice de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour les dépenses importantes de la famille, payer les intèrêts de son prêt et renforcer son activité de teinture.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aoua Traoré, 40, is the mother of 2 children (one girl and one boy) who lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her co-spouse, and their children in Koboïla II, a neighborhood of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Trained as a secretary and typist, she comes from a family of dyers in Quinzanbougou, one of the neighborhoods in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). She has been active in this business (which she had put on the back burner while she was studying) for almost 10 years. Well-known and appreciated, her clientele grows from day to day.

In order to satisfy this ever-growing clientele she joined the credit program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. She is requesting her first individual loan and intends to use it to buy 18 pieces of white "bazin" (cloth that is highly prized in West Africa), 250 kg of caustic soda, and 19 kg of dye of various colors.

She buys her raw materials in Bamako (white "bazin", caustic soda, and dyes). She dyes the cloth in her workshop opposite her home. Then she sells it for cash or credit; generally to women who themselves re-sell the dyed bazin, or to seamstresses or certain women from her neighborhood.

Mrs. Aoua Traoré expects to make a profit of 200,000 FCFA which will be used essentially for larger family expenses, and to make payments on the loan and further reinforce her dyeing business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of bazin (damask cloth), dye, and caustic soda

loans.name: Mame

texts.fr: Mame D. est une femme mariée, mère de 06 enfants. Elle souhaite renforcer son activité pour mieux subvenir aux charges familiales. Elle va faire un commerce de nététou (graine d’un arbre transformée en produit alimentaire local) et en même temps  acheter et vendre de la pate d’arachide. <b>Elle remboursera ce prêt en une seule échéance au bout de six mois<b/>.
texts.en:
Mame D. is a married woman and mother of six children. She wants to strengthen her business in order to better meet the family expenses. She is going to start a business in netetou (seeds from the Nere tree that are turned into a local food) and at the same time buy and sell peanut butter. She will repay this loan in a single installment after six months.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell netetou (seeds from the Nere tree that are turned into a local food)

loans.name: Stumai Saidi's Selous Group

texts.en:
Stumai S. is 30 and married with two daughters, ages twelve and three. She has owned a clothing business for the past five years. She sells clothes door-to-door and also delivers specific orders to her customers. She works daily from 9 am until 5 pm and earns a monthly profit of about $260.

Stumai has previously taken a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used it to increase her stock of clothes and has paid the loan back successfully. Stumai is now hoping for another loan to purchase clothes to sell for Iddi, the Muslim holiday celebrating the end of Ramadan.

Stumai is part of a group called Selous. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Stumai is in the center. The women on either side of her are part of her group, and Stumai will share this loan with them. One has a small grocery and the other owns a salon.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell for the Muslim holiday Iddi.

loans.name: Immaculée

texts.en:
Greetings from Immaculee in her hair salon business in Kigali, Rwanda. Immaculee is 51 years old and married with four children.

Immaculee has been in a group lending association since 2002. She owns her hair salon business for both women and men. She rents a house near a big Catholic church in Kigali. Most of her clients are the church's staff and other business ladies in Kigali. Fridays and Saturdays are the busiest days, because many ladies come to the salon for hair treatment. Saturdays are wedding days in Rwanda! 

She earns about $135 every month from her business. She employs three people to help her in the business. The challenge in her business is not having enough hair-drying helmets for the increasing number of clients. Therefore, she is applying for a loan worth 507,360 Frws to buy two hair-drying helmets for her salon.

loans.use: To buy two hair-drying helmets for her salon.

loans.name: Alima

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mairées vivant dans des foyers monogames avec en moyenne 02 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier Medine de Sikasso et se sont connues en raison du voisinage, des liens de parenté et d’amitié. Le groupe Benkadi travaille avec Soro Yiriwaso dépuis onze (11) ans et tous les prêts précédents ont été corrctement remboursés. 
Elles exercent des activités commerciales comme la vente des habits d’enfants, des savons, de l’encens. Les femmes du groupe Benkadi ont une grande expérience dans cette activité. Disposant d’un fonds de commerce personnel, elles comptent utiliser le prêt actuel comme appoint pour acquérir d’autres articles. Elles s’approvisionnent en général à Bamako (la capitale du Mali), en république de Cote d’ivoire ou au Togo.
Les produits sont vendus au marché de sikasso en gros ,en détails et au comptant . Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000 FCFA. Avec leur bénéfice, elle compte utiliser une partie dans les petites dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et l’autre partie dans leur activité de commerce. Les cinq femmes du groupe Benkadi espèrent garder leur cohésion et devenir toutes des grossistes disposant de magasins de vente dans la ville de Sikasso.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group are married women and housewives in monogamous families with an average of two (2) children. They live in the Medine district of Sikasso and are related by reasons of family ties, neighbors and friendship. The Benkadi group has worked with the Soro Yiriwaso (microbank) for eleven (11) years and all their previous loans have been successfully repaid.

Their carry out business activities such as the selling of childrens clothing, soaps, and incense. The women of the Benkadi group have substantial experience in these business activities. Though they already have existing personal business funds, they plan to use this loan to contribute to the purchase of additional products. They usually purchase their products in Bamako ( the capital of Mali), in the Republic of Ivory Coast, or in Togo.

The products are sold at the market in Sikasso, in wholesale or retail and for cash. They hope to each earn an average monthly income of 20,000 francs CFA. With their profits they plan to use a part for everyday family expenses and the other part for their business activities. The five women of the Benkadi group hope to maintain their cohesive association and eventually become wholesalers and proprietors of stores to sell in the city of Sikasso.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various articles for small business

loans.name: Asna Mrisho's Diamond Group

texts.en:
Asna M., age 35, is married with two sons ages 13 and 10. She has owned a general store since 2006 and works daily from 7am to 9pm. She is able to make a monthly profit of about US$ 87.

This will be Asna's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. The first, which she paid back successfully, was used to increase the stock of her shop. With the loan she hopes to receive now, she intends to expand her recently started welding business. She hopes this business will be an additional source of income for her and her family.

Asna is part of subgroup C of the Diamond Group. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. Her fellow group members own general stores, sell clothes, soap, eggs, and fish. In the picture, Asna is on the right.

loans.use: To expand welding business

loans.name: Tiba Juma Bilaly's Diamond Group

texts.en:
Tiba J. B. is 38 years old and married. She has no children yet. She owns a general store in an area called Tabatawhere where she sells food, soap, charcoal, and other items. She opened her shop in 2006. She works daily from 6 am to 9 pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $260.

Tiba has received two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania and has paid them back successfully. She used them to open a material shop where she makes clothes. She intends to use this third loan for the same purpose.

Tiba is part of subgroup A of the Diamond Group. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. Her fellow group members sell clothes, fish, and charcoal. In the picture, Tiba is the second from the left.

loans.use: To expand her material and fabrics shop.

loans.name: L'entente Est Bonne Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre (4) membres du groupe Benkadi (deux mariés et deux célibataires) ont une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans et 1 enfant. Elles vivent généralement dans des familles monogames dans le quartier Médine de la ville de  Sikasso.(troisième région économique de la république du Mali)
Elles font généralement le commerce de condiments alimentaires de charbon de bois et d’habits pour enfant. Les femmes du groupe Benkadi ont une relation de voisinage d’alliances et d’amitié. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire de groupe avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Les sources d’approvisionnement sont diverses et variées suivant les articles : pour le charbon de bois c’est essentiellement sur place et dans les villages environnants avec les paysans officiellement mandatés pour l’exercice de cette activité. Quant aux condiments alimentaires et les habits pour enfant ils sont achetés auprès des grossistes du grand marché de la ville de Sikasso.
Elles effectuent leurs ventes sur place à Sikasso en gros au comptant en détail et au marché surtout les jours de foire. Leur clientèle est composée de forains grossistes venant des villes, de femmes et de quelques hommes.
Avec ce prêt les membres du groupe Benkadi comptent réaliser des bénéfices moyens mensuels de 30.000FCFA qu’elles utiliseront à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans leurs activités respectives.
texts.en:
The four (4) members of the Benkadi group ( two married and two single women) are on average, 31 years of age and have one (1) child. In general, they live in monogamous families in the neighborhood of Medine in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region in the republic of Mali). Their businesses are in the sale of basic food condiments, charcoal, and children's clothing. The women of the Benkadi group have a relationship that is friendly and mutually beneficial. This is their fifth group loan taken together through the loan program at the Siri Yiriwaso microbank. All their previous loans have been properly repaid.

The sources where they purchase their provisions are diverse and varied but follow the group's articles: Charcoal is usually made in place in the surrounding villages from specified individuals, mandated to produce this product. As for the basic condiments and children's clothing, they are purchased in bulk from wholesalers at the central market in the city of Sikasso.

They sell their items in the Sikasso marketplace, mostly for cash and especially when there are fair days at the market. Their clients are made up of stall owners, wholesalers from other towns, women and some men.

With the loan the members of the Benkadi group expect to earn profits averaging 30,000 francs CFA which will be used to meet the loan payments and invest the remainder in their respective business activities.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal, basic food condiments and children's clothing.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Danaya est un regroupement de six femmes ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent avec leurs enfants et époux dans des familles monogames au quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Unies par des relations essentiellement professionnelle et de voisinage, ces femmes exercent le commerce des produits de beauté(de differentes sortes laits, crèmes, pommades, lotions... et des chaussures(généralement en plastique).
Afin de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus croissante de la clientèle, les membres de Danaya ont décidé ensemble d’intégrer le programme.Ils sont à leur  première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles comptent achèter  avec ce prêt, au grand marché de Sikasso 40 paires de chaussures en plastique, 10 cartons de produits de beauté de differentes games. 
Les produits ainsi achetés seront vendus  dans la ville de Sikasso en ambulant, au marché du quartier de Médine et dans les foires des villages environnants pour la plupart en détail et au comptant à une clientèle essentiellement féminine. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000FCFAqui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt et subvenir aux charges de la famille.
texts.en:
Danaya is a merger of six women with an average of 33 years of age and 3 children. They live with their children and spouses in monogamous families in the Hamdallaye area in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). United by professional relations and by being neighbors, these women are involved in the sale of beauty products (various types of milks, cremes, pommades, lotions) and shoes (generally plastic). In order to satisfy the increasing demands of their customers, members of Danaya have decided to integrate their plans. Their first experience is now, with Soro Yiriwaso. They plan to purchase, with this loan, in the large market of Sikasso 40 pairs of plastic shoes and 10 cartons of different types of beauty products. The products bought will then be sold in the city of Sikasso through mobile methods, at the market in the Médine area and in the fairs in the surrounding villages comprised mostly of female customers. They are hoping to earn a profit of aproximately 20,000 FCFA per month (about $ 43) which will be used to pay off the interest on this loan and to serve the needs of thier families.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products and shoes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Danaya (La Confince) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe(deux mariés et deux célibataires) Danaya  de l’association Soro Yiriwa de Médine ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et 1 enfant. Elles vivent dans des familles nucleaires au quartier Médine de la ville de Sikasso( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues dans le quartier en raison du voisinage.
Elles font généralement le commerce d’habits pour enfants, de savons (de fabrication moderne et traditionnelle), de charbon de bois, des produits alimentaires et  divers articles.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités les femmes du groupe Danaya ont décidé ensemble de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso qui accepta de leur octroyer leur sixième prêt. et  tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt,  10 douzaines d’habits pour enfants,  5 cartons de savon de toilette, 2 sacs de savon de fabrication traditionnelle (gabacourouni)et divers articles alimentaires.
Généralement, elles se ravitaillent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso auprès des grossistes pour les revendre sur place à Sikasso (à domicile) et dans les villages environnants les jours de foire en détails, au comptant ou à crédit. Les marchandises sont soit étalées sur des tables (au marché du quartier de Médine) ou mises dans des tasses pour les vendre de porte en porte. La clientèle est composée de femmes et quelques fois des hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice par cycle de 60. 000FCFA, lequel sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses quotidiennes des familles, payer les intérêts du prêt  et investir le reste dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Danaya (two married women and two single women) of the Soro Yiriwa of Medicine assocation are on average 30 years of age with one child. They live with nuclear families in the Médine area of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They know each other due to being neighbors in the area. They are involved in the general business of clothing for children, soaps (made both traditionally and from modern methods), charcoal, food products and diverse other items. In order to increase the size of their sales these women of the Danaya group decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso which agreed to provide them with a sixth loan. All previous loans were paid back on time. With this loan, they are planning to purchase 10 dozen clothes for children, 5 boxes of body soap, 2 bags of soap manufactured traditionally (gabacourouni) and various food products. Generally, they obtain fresh supplies from the large market in the city of Sikasso from the bulk vendors and re-sell them door to door in Sikasso and in the surrounding villages during market days for cash or credit. The merchandise are either displayed on tables (at the market in the area of Médine) or put in bags to be sold from door to door. The customers are mostly women and sometimes men. They plan to earn a profit of 60,000 FCFA per cycle (approximately $ 130), which would be used to support daily expenses of the families, repay interest on the loan and invest in the rest of their activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothes for children, soaps and other items

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina L. lives in Cameroon's North West province and hopes to take out a new loan from GHAPE after repaying a previous one.

Regina runs a successful business selling household utensils from a stall near the centre of Bamenda, a medium-sized town in the country's Anglophone west, and would like to use a new loan to buy extra items to sell to her customers. Married with seven children, Regina will use the extra income made possible by this loan to pay school fees for the two children who still live at home with her. She says she hopes the loan will help her to take good care of her family.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace F. has been a GHAPE client for nearly seven years.  She is 49, widowed and has six children. 

Grace's first loan was for $38, and she used it to grow yams on her farm. Since that time, she has used other loans to expand her businesses and increase her income. GHAPE has a policy of increasing loan size only when borrowers have shown they are responsible. As a long-standing member with an excellent repayment record, Grace has consistently been able to apply for larger loans over the last two years. 

Grace plans to invest her new loan in a machine for inflating car and motorbike tires. She also plans to hire someone to operate the machine when she cannot be present. 

Sadly, Grace lost her husband when her sons and daughters were very young, but she has used money from previous loans to help buy books and pay her children's school fees. In addition to educating her children, Grace says that she wants to maintain a good house, and save some of her profit to invest in building her business and creating a larger income for herself and her family in the future.

loans.use: To buy a machine to inflate car and motorbike tires.

loans.name: Tienkadi (La Vérité Est Bonne) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tienkadi est composé de femmes mariées vivant en générale dans des foyers polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 3 enfants et résidant dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de  Sikasso (troisième région économique du Mali).
Ces femmes exercent le commerce de savons (de toilette, de lessive de fabrication locale) des condiments alimentaires et  autres articles. Unies par des liens de parenté et d’alliance, les femmes du groupe décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe.
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 6 cartons de savons et une importante quantité de condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso (quelques fois à Bamako et au Burkina Faso) auprès des grossistes attitrés et dans les localités environnantes auprès de paysans producteurs de  légumineuses (tel les choux, piments, oignons). Ensuite elles viennent  revendre ces articles dans les quartiers de façon ambulante, dans les marchés avec une place fixe sous des hangars. Les ventes sont en majorité au comptant et quelques fois à crédit. La clientèle est composée essentiellement  des femmes .
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 17.500FCFA, lequel sera reinvesti dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Tienkado group is composed of married women generally living in polygamous households in the Hamdallaye area of the city of Sikasso (third largest economic region of Mali) and are on average 35 years old and have 3 children. These women buy and sell soaps (locally made body soap and laundry soap), food condiments and other items. United by blood and marriage relationships, the women in the group decided to be involved with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and they are currently on their first loan from the group. With this loan they plan on purchasing 6 boxes of soap and a large quantity of food condiments. They generally get supplies from the large market in the city of Sikasso (also sometimes from Bamako and in Burkina Faso) from bulk sellers and in surrounding areas from rural producers of vegetables (such as cabbage, peppers, onions). Then they re-sell these items in the neighborhoods in a mobile way (door to door) or in the markets with a fixed spot under hangars. Sales are generally in cash and sometimes for credit. Their customers are essentially women. They hope to earn a monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA (approximately $ 38) which would be reinvested into their activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing soaps and food condiments

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy L. is 56 years old and has seven children.

She has been a GHAPE client for six years. Due to her impressive repayment record, her loans have gradually increased in size since her first loan, which was for $38. Over the years she has used her loans skilfully to expand her farming businesses and increase her income.

This year, Dorothy has applied for a larger loan which she will repay over 24 months. She plans to invest the money in a plot of land on which she will build living accommodations for students in the village of Alabukam. She intends to supplement the loan with some of her own money.

Dorothy says she will use the profit generated by this project to help her family, including paying fees for three of her children who are still at school.

Dorothy is keen to continue as a member of GHAPE, because she says over the years the loans and training she has received have helped her very much.

loans.use: Purchase of a plot of land to build living accommodations for students.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
53-year-old John A. has been a borrower with GHAPE in Cameroon for three years. He has invested his loans in various farming projects, including, most recently, raising pigs.

John has recently applied for a slightly increased loan to expand his farm output. He proposes to repay the money over 24 months and is confident that his experience in rearing pigs will make this venture a success.

John is married with seven children, five of whom are still living with him, including one who has been ill for many years. He says the increased profit from his business will help him take good care of them.

loans.use: Purchase pigs.

loans.name: Yankadi (Bon Endroit) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Yankadi sont des femmes mairées monogames avec en moyenne deux (2) enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Sikasso et se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font généralement le petit commerce de divers articles notamment la vente de fruits, de legumes, de céréales et de charbon. 

Dans leurs soucis de renforcer leurs activités, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso ou elles sont à leur premier prêt. 

Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 10 sacs de fruits et de legumes, 20 sacs de céréales et 20 sacs de charbon. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement lors des foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants et au marché de sikasso. 

Les produits sont vendus au marché de sikasso en gros ,en détails ou au comptant. Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 20.000 FCFA .
texts.en:
The members of the Yankadi group are married and monogamous women who have, on average, two children. They live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood in Sikasso and became acquainted through bonds of vicinity and friendship. Their typical business consists in selling various products, in particular fruits, vegetables, cereals and charcoal. Anxious to bolster their businesses, they decided to join the micro-credit program of Soro Yiriwaso for a first loan. With this loan, they intend to buy 10 sacks of fruits and vegetables, 20 sacks of cereals, and 20 sacks of charcoal. They usually do their shopping during weekly fairs in the surrounding villages, and in the Sikasso market. The products are then resold, retail, wholesale or for cash, in the Sikasso market. They hope to make of monthly profit of 20.000 XOF each.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products (fruits, vegetables, cereals and charcoal) for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Yacouba K. est un célibataire de 26 ans  qui vit avec ses cadets chez son feu grand père à Kaboila II, au centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali en Afrique de l’Ouest). Après plusieurs activités économiques sans succès, il s’est spécialisé dans la vente de materiels audio- visuels et  electroniques ( téléviseur, DVD, radios, cassettes, panneaux solaires, antennes paraboliques etc...) depuis  maintenant 4ans.
Il  s’approvisionne généralement au Ghana (en Afrique de l’Ouest)  et  vend ses articles au comptant en détail ou en demi gros à Sikasso dans sa boutique sise au grand marché. Sa clientèle est essentiellement composée de voyageurs, de routiers, de jeunes mélomanes de la ville de Sikasso. En plus des matériels audio visuels, Monsieur K. vend des fournitures scolaires et de bureau. Il jouit d’une grande réputaion et d’une très forte  confiance de sa clientèle, ce qui lui a permis d’avoir la commande du Lycée privée Amion GUINDO de Sikasso pour ses fournitures scolaires.
Pour faire face à une clientèle de plus en plus grandissante, il décida  obtenir des ressources complémentaires auprès de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son premier prêt indivuduel.
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter un téléviseur, une radio minichaine, des cassettes vidéos, et 25 cartons de cahier scolaire. Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 100.000 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yacouba K.,age 26, is single and lives with his younger brothers in the house of his deceased grandfather in Kaboila II, in downtown Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali, Western Africa). After starting several unsuccessful businesses, he's been specializing in the sale of audiovisual equipments and electronic devices (TV sets, DVDs, radios, tapes, solar panels, parabolic antennas, etc...) for four years. He usually does his shopping in Ghana (Western Africa) and sells his goods for cash, wholesale or retail, in his shop in the grand market of Sikasso. His clientele is mostly composed of travelers, truck drivers, and young music lovers from the city of Sikasso. In addition to audiovisual equipments, Mr. K. also sells school and office supplies. He is very well regarded and entrusted by his clientele, which enabled him to get an order for school supplies from the private high school Amion GUINDO in Sikasso. To meet increasing customer demand, he decided to seek a first individual loan from Soro Yiriwaso to obtain additional resources. With this loan, he intends to buy one TV set, one compact stereo system, video tapes, and 25 boxes of school notebooks. He reckon that he will make a profit of 100.000 XOF, to be used to repay the loan and invest in his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy audiovisual equipments and school supplies

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en:
Greetings from Chantal in Kicukiro, Rwanda! Chantal is 39 years old, married with 4 children and takes care of 2 adopted orphans. Chantal owns a hardware shop in Kicukiro center in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. She sells electric bulbs, paint, building nails, iron sheets for roofing, locks, and cement. She employs 3 people in the business. 

This client is requesting a loan worth 521 075 Frws to buy more items for her hardware shop because of the increasing number of customers.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Mathias

texts.en:
Mathias N. has been a member of GHAPE since 2004, and has used several loans to expand his farm.

Like some other long-term loan recipients, Mathias is keen to diversify his business beyond agriculture. To that end, he hopes this loan will allow him to buy a motorbike and cover the associated registration and insurance costs. In this part of Cameroon, bikes are a good way of moving goods and people to and from town, as the roads become impassable to bigger vehicles after it rains.

Mathias speaks highly of the good that GHAPE has done for him and his community. He says it is the first NGO to come to his area, and it has taught people about living in healthy places, educated their children and explained business development to him and many of his neighbors.

Mathias is single and says he wants to use profits of his labour to look after his health and education, and ultimately to build a house.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and cover associated costs.

loans.name: Sidiki

texts.fr:
Monsieur Sidiki O. a 32 ans et vit avec ses 3 enfants, son épouse,  ses frères et soeurs chez son feu père à Mancourani I, un des quartiers de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après le décès de son père, Sidiki l’aîné de la famille comme l’exige la tradition devait s’occuper de la famille. Ainsi il fut obliger d’abandonner les études et entamer une activité génératrice de revenus afin de subvenir aux besoins de la famille. Il entama l’apprentissage du métier de tailleur auprès de plusieurs maîtres tailleurs de la ville de Sikasso. Après 17 ans d’expériences, il devient un maître tailleur connu de tout Sikasso. Son atélier  situé au grand marché de cette ville est un creusset de styles et de modèles qui est très visité par une clientèle variée.  
C’est pour faire face aux demandes de plus en plus croissantes et exigeantes de cette clientèle, qu’il décida d’intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin d’acquérir une nouvelle machine à broder, acheter 7 pièces de bazin teintés à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) et  200 mètres de tissus pour hommes à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso en Afrique de l’Ouest) pour les coudre (en chemises et pantalons) avant de les revendre. En raison de la marge bénéficiaire très intéressante monsieur O. compte  réaliser 150.000 FCFA de surplus qui sera utilisé pour subvenir essentiellement aux besoins de sa famille élargie.
texts.en:
Mr. Sidiki O., age 32, lives with his three children, his wife, and his brothers and sisters, in the home of his deceased father in Mancourani I, one of the neighborhoods in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After his father passed away, Sidiki, the elder son, had to take care of the family, as required by tradition. For this reason, he had to abandon his studies and start making money to provide for his family. He was trained as a tailor by several master tailors in the city of Sikasso. After 17 years of experience, he became a master tailor known all over Sikasso. His workshop, located in the grand market, is a melting pot of styles and designs, and is very much visited by a diverse clientele. To satisfy an increasing number of ever more demanding requests from his customers, he decided to join the loan program of the microfinance organisation Soro Yiriwaso, in order to buy a new embroidery machine, seven pieces of tinted "bazin" (a sort of damask) in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali), and 200 meters of men's fabric in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso, Western Africa). He intends to sew them to make shirts and trousers, that he will then sell. Due to an interesting profit margin, Mr. O. expects to make a profit of 150.000 XOF, to be used mainly to meet his family expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new embroidery machine and fabrics

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Greetings from Bernadette in Kacyiru, Rwanda! She is 30 years old and married with 4 children. Bernadette owns her shop in Kacyiru town, which she opened up in 2000. She sells various items such as biscuits, sugar, cassava flour, small fish, drinks, etc. She employs two people in her business.

Bernadette is looking for a loan worth 521,075 Frws to buy more items to increase her stock. Her loan will be repaid monthly for 8 months.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana is 49 years old and lives with her husband Pori, who is in the sales business. She has two daughters, 29 year-old Nery and 24 year-old Derly, who is in higher education. Ana has 20 years of experience in grocery sales, always working in her some store, which she can manage without much trouble since it is in her own home. She begins working at 6 am and finishes at 9pn, during those hours she serves her customers, which she has been attracting throughout the years. Se loves her jobs, since because of it she has been able to give her children a higher level of education, which they have eagerly and fully taken advantage of. The difficult part of her job is having to stay in the tiny store all day, without going out for a second to rest or visit her daughters who live in the city, since she works during the entire week. Ana wants to see her daughter form their own families and to have a better future. She will supply her store with products that people ask for with the loan money, and in that way continue to maintain customer loyalty and attract new customers, so that in the future she will be able to open another store.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy Juárez, Kiva volunteer.

Ana tiene 49 años, vive con su esposo Pori, que se dedica al comercio, tiene dos hijas; Nery de 29 y Derly de 24, la cual cursa superiores.
